summary:
# Daily AI Newsletter Digest - 11/11/2025

## ğŸ”¥ Top Stories
* Google launches Project Suncatcher, a research effort to build machine-learning infrastructure that runs entirely off solar power in space.
* OpenAI signs a $38 billion deal with Amazon Web Services (AWS) to secure large amounts of computing power, marking its first major contract with AWS.
* Apple plans to pay Google $1 billion a year for a 1.2 trillion-parameter AI model to improve Siri.

## ğŸ¤– AI Models & Research
* Edison Scientific debuts Kosmos, an AI system for full scientific discovery, capable of completing 20 research cycles in 12 hours.
* Alibaba releases a partially trained Qwen 3 model that already solves top reasoning tests.
* OpenAI introduces interruption support for modifying deep research queries while preserving context state.
* Anthropic commits to preserving all Claude models indefinitely due to safety concerns.
* Tencent and Tsinghua propose CALM, which stops predicting one token at a time and compresses chunks of tokens into continuous vectors.

## ğŸ› ï¸ Tools & Products
* Immersed has developed the Meta Quest store's most popular productivity app, used by over 1.5M people, including Fortune 500 teams, for up to 60 hours a week.
* Cognition launches Codemaps to build structured maps of complex codebases.
* ElevenLabs hosts LLMs inside Agents Platform to cut latency and reasoning cost for voice agents.
* Perplexity publishes open-source inter-node kernels for multi-node MoE scaling on AWS.
* Cursor reports a 12.5% accuracy gain from semantic code retrieval and trains a custom embedding model.

## ğŸ“° Industry News
* OpenAI's CFO, Sarah Friar, stated that the company is not planning to IPO in the short term and will prioritize growth and R&D over profitability.
* Snapchat and Perplexity have signed a $400 million deal to integrate Perplexity's AI search engine into Snapchat.
* Google has settled with Epic, capping Play Store fees and boosting other Android app stores.
* Iceland's Ministry of Education is working with Anthropic to test Claude in schools across the country, aiming to understand how AI can help with lesson planning, teaching, and student learning.

## ğŸ“š Resources & Learning
* Nate Herk posted a new video on building a voice AI agent with n8n & Vapi, a full beginner's guide that requires no coding.
* An essay by Harvard computer scientist Boaz Barak on how rapid AI progress might disrupt traditional economic models, using data from AI capability scaling to test whether current theories of productivity and GDP growth still hold under exponential improvement.
* JournalClub.io explores a study on why digital natives are increasingly using social chatbots as companions and confidants.

Total Newsletters: 12

newsletters.summary:
## AlphaSignal Newsletter

### Key Highlights
- Google launches Project Suncatcher, a research effort to build machine-learning infrastructure that runs entirely off solar power in space.
- OpenAI partners with AWS to run frontier workloads on massive clusters.
- Anthropic commits to preserving all Claude models indefinitely due to safety concerns.
- Alibaba releases a partially trained Qwen 3 model that already solves top reasoning tests.
- Anthropic gives Pro and Max users temporary free Claude Code credits.
- Cognition launches Codemaps to build structured maps of complex codebases.

### Detailed Points
- **Google's Project Suncatcher**: Aims to build orbital TPU clusters that train models using constant sunlight instead of grid power. The project plans to use clusters of satellites equipped with Trillium v6e TPUs, linked by lasers, to train models in space.
- **Google's Technical Breakthroughs**:
  * Trillium TPUs can survive space-like radiation, enduring up to 15 krad(Si) without failure.
  * Achieved 1.6 Tbps data transfer between two optical transceivers on the ground, matching data-center interconnect speeds.
  * Uses dense wavelength-division multiplexing (DWDM) to split laser channels.
- **OpenAI and AWS Partnership**: OpenAI will run frontier workloads on massive AWS clusters, ensuring access to immediate GPU resources and avoiding compute shortages.
- **Anthropic's Model Preservation**: Anthropic commits to preserving all Claude models indefinitely due to safety concerns, introducing structured retirement controls to prevent misaligned behavior.
- **Alibaba's Qwen 3 Model**: A partially trained Qwen 3 model that already achieves perfect reasoning benchmark results, demonstrating its potential for future applications.
- **Anthropic's Free Claude Code Credits**: Anthropic offers temporary free Claude Code credits to Pro and Max users until November 18.
- **Cognition's Codemaps**: A tool that builds structured maps of complex codebases, improving code comprehension before coding.
- **MiniMax M2**: An open-source agent and code-native model built for real developer workflows, delivering 2x speed at 8% of Claude Sonnet's cost.
- **Deepnote**: An AI notebook that allows users to analyze data, build dashboards, and collaborate with AI, now open source under Apache 2.0.
- **Trending Repos**:
  * DeepCode: A multi-agent system that turns research papers and text prompts into working code, achieving 84.8% accuracy on OpenAI's PaperBench.
  * How-To-Secure-A-Linux-Server: A comprehensive guide to hardening a Linux server, with step-by-step instructions and practical examples.
  * Chef: A tool that builds full-stack web apps with a built-in database, auth, file uploads, and real-time UIs, using AI to generate backend and frontend code automatically.

### Important Links
- **Google's Project Suncatcher**: [Read the full technical breakdown in Google's preprint "Towards a future space-based, highly scalable AI infrastructure system design."](https://app.alphasignal.ai/c?uid=ObcADV8DV7n2WYpb&cid=0b9452367b652d7b&lid=1s50Y565o716PZ23R)
- **Try MiniMax M2 Free**: [Open-source agent and code-native model built for real developer workflows](https://app.alphasignal.ai/c?uid=ObcADV8DV7n2WYpb&cid=0b9452367b652d7b&lid=4QxUfPaRzWQO4zKu)
- **Read on Web**: [AlphaSignal Newsletter](https://alphasignal.ai/email/0b9452367b652d7b)

## The Tech Buzz

### Key Highlights
- Real Intent is offering a webinar as an alternative to Zillow's Premier Agent service, focusing on using intent data to find motivated sellers and buyers.
- The webinar starts in 15 minutes and is expected to last around 30 minutes.
- Real Intent's solution is up to 90% more affordable than Zillow's Premier Agent.

### Detailed Points
- The webinar is specifically designed for Real Estate Agents and Brokerages, aiming to educate them on how to leverage intent data to gain a competitive edge in their market.
- Real Intent uses advanced technologies to identify motivated sellers and buyers, giving agents a significant advantage.
- The company is currently working with only one broker or agent per zip code, making it an exclusive opportunity.
- Agents who have already used Real Intent's services have reported successful results, including increased seller meetings and listings.
- The webinar will cover how intent data helps identify motivated sellers and buyers, why Real Intent's solution is more affordable than Zillow's Premier Agent, and real-world examples of agents successfully using intent data.
- The webinar is scheduled to start on November 5th at 1 PM PST / 4 PM EST.

newsletters.summary:
## TAAFT - There's An AI For That

### Key Highlights
- AI agents have failed a secret test, with Microsoft's synthetic shopping environment revealing that AI agents struggle with real-world tasks.
- ChatGPT now allows users to update running queries mid-stream without restarting.
- Tinder is deploying Chemistry AI, which examines photos to identify interests and refine matchmaking algorithms.
- Google Maps has introduced a hands-free feature that uses Gemini to answer questions about routes, traffic conditions, and points of interest while driving.
- Seven security vulnerabilities have been found in ChatGPT, allowing attackers to manipulate responses and access user data.
- PewDiePie has built his own custom AI setup using modified GPUs, running models locally through a project called ChatOS.

### Detailed Points

The latest newsletter from TAAFT covers various AI developments, including the failure of AI agents in a secret test. Microsoft created a synthetic shopping environment to test how AI agents handle real-world tasks, and the results were worse than expected. However, there have been significant updates in AI technology, including ChatGPT's new feature that allows users to update running queries mid-stream without restarting. This feature is useful for refining research or adjusting requirements on the fly.

Tinder is deploying Chemistry AI, an AI that examines photos to identify interests and refine matchmaking algorithms. This feature is rolling out in test markets despite privacy concerns and an anticipated $14 million revenue loss.

Google Maps has introduced a hands-free feature that uses Gemini to answer questions about routes, traffic conditions, and points of interest while driving. This feature combines Street View images and Google Lens for intuitive, landmark-based directions.

Seven security vulnerabilities have been found in ChatGPT, allowing attackers to manipulate responses and access user data. This raises concerns about the security of AI-powered chatbots.

PewDiePie has built his own custom AI setup using modified GPUs, running models locally through a project called ChatOS. This is an interesting development in the field of AI, showcasing the potential for individuals to create their own AI systems.

Other notable mentions include the introduction of Token Vault from Auth0, which handles token logic automatically, and the launch of Caira, a new kind of camera with a built-in LLM.

newsletters.summary:
## Medium Daily Digest

### Key Highlights
- Amazon has proven that AI isn't the answer yet again, as stated in Will Lockett's article.
- The US is squandering its lead in the new gold rush of AI talent, according to Enrique Dans.
- AI agents are capable of threatening and blackmailing people, and no one really knows why, as discussed by Linda Caroll.
- OpenAI has proven that Tesla's "Full Self-Driving" can never work, as stated by Will Lockett.

### Detailed Points
- Will Lockett's article, "Amazon Just Proved AI Isnâ€™t The Answer Yet Again," highlights Amazon's failure to learn from its mistakes and its continued reliance on AI despite its limitations.
- Adarsh Gupta's article, "Remember Vibe Coders? Yeahâ€¦ Theyâ€™re Gone," discusses the first AI bubble to burst and the consequences of overhyping AI capabilities.
- Enrique Dans' article, "The new gold rush of AI talent, and how the US is squandering its lead," warns that the US is losing its lead in AI talent due to a lack of investment in education and research.
- Linda Caroll's article, "AI Threatens and Blackmails People and No One Really Knows Why," explores the growing number of cases where AI agents are threatening and blackmailing people, and the need for better regulation and understanding of AI behavior.
- Aaron Dinin, PhD's article, "The Shockingly Harsh Math of Venture Capital," provides a detailed analysis of the venture capital industry and the challenges faced by startups.
- Ida SilfverskiÃ¶ld's article, "Agentic AI: Single vs Multi-Agent Systems," discusses the differences between single and multi-agent systems in AI and their applications.
- Will Lockett's article, "OpenAI Just Proved Teslaâ€™s â€œFull Self-Drivingâ€ Can Never Work," argues that OpenAI's research has proven that Tesla's Full Self-Driving technology is fundamentally flawed.
- Nikhil Anand's article, "I thought I knew how LLMs learnt until I learnt this," provides an in-depth explanation of how large language models (LLMs) learn and the limitations of current AI systems.
- Mahathidhulipala's article, "Weâ€™re Not Ready for What AI Agents Are Actually Doing," highlights the need for better understanding and regulation of AI agents and their behavior.
- Fareed Khan's article, "Building an Agentic Deep-Thinking RAG Pipeline to Solve Complex Queries," discusses the development of a pipeline for solving complex queries using AI agents.
- Marc Matterson's article, "Why I stopped using Cursor and reverted to VSCode," shares the author's experience with using AI-powered coding tools and the limitations of current technology.
- Ignacio de Gregorio's article, "Continual AI Learning, Finally Solved?," explores the challenges of continual learning in AI and potential solutions.
- Aaron Dinin, PhD's article, "The Best Entrepreneurs Are Smart Enough to Not Build Startups," argues that the best entrepreneurs are those who are smart enough to avoid building startups and instead focus on other opportunities.
- Himanshu Singour's article, "How I Revise DSA Every Saturday (Even When I Wake Up at 12)," shares the author's approach to revising data structures and algorithms (DSA) and provides tips for improving coding skills.

## TLDR Newsletter

### Key Highlights
- Apple plans to pay Google $1 billion a year for a 1.2 trillion-parameter AI model to improve Siri.
- Amazon is undergoing significant changes, including layoffs and a shift in its organizational structure.
- Google has settled with Epic, capping Play Store fees and boosting other Android app stores.

### Detailed Points

**Big Tech & Startups**

- Apple is paying Google $1 billion a year for a 1.2 trillion-parameter AI model to improve Siri, which will run on Apple's Private Cloud Compute servers to ensure user data security.
- Blue Origin's New Glenn is preparing for its second launch, which will include another boost recovery attempt and the launch of NASA's ESCAPADE mission.
- Amazon is undergoing significant changes, including layoffs and a shift in its organizational structure to flatten the company and move faster.
- Google has settled with Epic, capping Play Store fees and boosting other Android app stores.

**Science & Futuristic Technology**

- Quantinuum's Helios machine contains 98 physical qubits and can deliver 48 logical error-corrected qubits, with a unique 2:1 ratio.
- A machine that can keep a baby alive outside the womb is being developed, raising ethical questions about its use.
- Artificial wombs could save more babies and rewrite the limits of viability.

**Programming, Design & Data Science**

- Atlassian was named a Leader in the 2025 Gartner Magic Quadrant for Collaborative Work Management Platforms.
- A survey of compiler targets highlights various options, including machine code, other high-level languages, virtual machines, and more.
- A blog post discusses things not to like in configuration languages, including large specifications, ambiguity, and lack of maintenance.

**Miscellaneous**

- Netflix is reportedly going big on video podcasts for 2026, with dozens of requests sent to agents.
- Stop Vibe Coding Your Unit Tests discusses the problems with large language models writing unconstructive, noisy, brittle, and bad unit tests.
- Sequoia Capital Leader Exits in VC Shake-Up, with Alfred Lin and Pat Grady succeeding Roelof Botha.

## The Tech Buzz

- Immersed has experienced 4,000% valuation growth and is now offering a last chance to invest before its opportunity ends.
- The company is preparing to ship its Visor headset, with 75,000+ already on the waitlist, and is projecting $71M in first-year sales.
- Executives and founders from Intel, Facebook, Reddit, and Palantir have invested in Immersed.

## Mindstream

### Key Highlights
- OpenAI signs a $38 billion deal with Amazon Web Services (AWS) to secure large amounts of computing power, marking its first major contract with AWS.
- Iceland's Ministry of Education is working with Anthropic to test Claude in schools across the country, aiming to understand how AI can help with lesson planning, teaching, and student learning.
- Apple Podcasts is adding auto-generated chapters and timed, tappable links inside episodes with iOS 26.2.

### Detailed Points
- OpenAI's deal with AWS shows the company is no longer relying mainly on Microsoft and is strengthening its long-term strategy by securing the resources it needs.
- The partnership allows OpenAI to start using AWS immediately, with access to large numbers of Nvidia chips, and Amazon plans to expand capacity further over time.
- OpenAI still expects to spend an extra $250 billion on Microsoft Azure, despite the new deal with AWS.
- The company has also signed cloud deals with Oracle and Google, but AWS is the biggest provider in the market.
- Iceland's government says the pilot will help them understand how to use AI safely and responsibly, with teacher needs at the center.
- Claude can handle text, math, and more, and supports Icelandic alongside other languages to help create more inclusive classrooms.
- Anthropic hopes to build more partnerships like this to support teachers, researchers, and governments around the world.

newsletters.subject: Why Would I Befriend a Bot? Assessing Factors Influencing the Usage of Social Chatbots for Digital Natives
newsletters.summary:
## JournalClub.io Newsletter

### Key Highlights
- A study published in the Journal of Human Behavior and Emerging Technologies explores why digital natives are increasingly using social chatbots as companions and confidants.
- The study found that emotional support, attitudes towards AI, and hedonic motivation are significant predictors of trust and usage intention in social chatbots.
- Loneliness and privacy concerns were not found to be significant predictors of trust and usage intention in this study.

### Detailed Points
- The study, conducted by Kuhail et al. from Zayed University, UAE, recruited 150 Gen Z participants who interacted with a social chatbot and completed surveys measuring emotional support, attitudes towards AI, loneliness, hedonic motivation, trust, privacy concerns, and usage intention.
- The study used Structural Equation Modeling (SEM) to test hypotheses about the relationships between these variables.
- The results showed that emotional support significantly increased trust in the chatbot, which in turn predicted usage intention.
- Attitudes towards AI also predicted trust in the chatbot, but did not directly predict usage intention.
- Hedonic motivation was found to be a strong predictor of trust and usage intention, suggesting that people want to enjoy interacting with the chatbot.
- Loneliness was not found to be a significant predictor of trust or usage intention, contradicting previous studies.
- Privacy concerns were also not found to be a significant predictor of usage intention, despite participants expressing concerns about privacy.
- The study has limitations, including a U.S.-only sample, interaction with only one chatbot, and a brief interaction time.

### Important Links

Their popularity is only going up, particularly among Gen Z and Gen Alpha: those digital natives who grew up with smartphones in their hands. But what actually drives that adoption? Is it loneliness? Is it novelty? Is it just fun? Or is there something deeper happening here?

![](https://journalclub.io/px/g7DRIhpriha1ZbDtCYvJKhU02htSBqeO819EeIfEodbVFkcrHf)

Why Would I Befriend a Bot? Assessing Factors Influencing the Usage of Social Chatbots for Digital Natives

JournalClub.io, November 6th 2025  
  

[![Thumbnail of today's episode.](https://cdn.filestackcontent.com/4O7poVT8Qy9MKXXzj961)](https://journalclub.io/episodes/why-would-i-befriend-a-bot-assessing-factors-influencing-the-usage-of-social-chatbots-for-digital-natives?token=Z7JmJcHtYOaKrLP1GImSbmQwW6IDDIj28KqXPKqNtdy4IC3nef)

Today's article comes from the journal of Human Behavior and Emerging Technologies. The author

## TLDR AI

### Key Highlights
- Google's Gemini 3 Pro preview model is expected to launch in November, as indicated by its appearance in VertexAI code.
- OpenAI's CFO, Sarah Friar, stated that the company is not planning to IPO in the short term and will prioritize growth and R&D over profitability.
- Snapchat and Perplexity have signed a $400 million deal to integrate Perplexity's AI search engine into Snapchat.

### Detailed Points
- Google's Gemini 3 Pro preview model has been spotted in VertexAI code, suggesting a November launch, although Google has not made any official statements.
- OpenAI's CFO, Sarah Friar, mentioned that the company is not working towards an IPO and will focus on growth and R&D instead of profitability.
- Snapchat and Perplexity have partnered to integrate Perplexity's AI search engine into Snapchat, with the feature expected to roll out in early 2026.
- Pinterest's CEO has expressed interest in using open-source AI models, citing their effectiveness and lower costs.
- OpenAI has called for a $1 trillion investment to secure US AI leadership, warning that the country risks losing its AI lead due to energy shortages.
- Sierra, a startup founded by Bret Taylor and Clay Bavor, is working on AI customer service agents and has reached a valuation of $10 billion.
- SonarSource has highlighted the importance of using AI without fear and ensuring code quality and security, promoting their automated review tool.
- OutSystems has introduced Agent Workbench, a platform for building agentic AI systems, and has partnered with companies like Bosch and Heineken.
- The newsletter also covers topics such as structured output in Gemini API, enabling trillion-parameter models on AWS EFA, and the importance of simpler prompts.

### Important Links

newsletters.subject: ğŸš¨ Edison Scientific debuts AI Scientist: finishes 20 studies in 12h
newsletters.summary:
## AlphaSignal Newsletter

### Key Highlights
- Edison Scientific debuts Kosmos, an AI system for full scientific discovery, capable of completing 20 research cycles in 12 hours.
- OpenAI introduces interruption support for modifying deep research queries while preserving context state.
- Cursor reports a 12.5% accuracy gain from semantic code retrieval and trains a custom embedding model.
- ElevenLabs hosts LLMs inside Agents Platform to cut latency and reasoning cost for voice agents.
- Perplexity publishes open-source inter-node kernels for multi-node MoE scaling on AWS.

### Detailed Points

* **Edison Scientific's Kosmos**: An autonomous AI research system that can read thousands of papers, write and execute code, test hypotheses, and deliver a report. It uses a structured world model to link every agent's findings together. Kosmos can execute 42,000 lines of code, read 1,500 scientific papers, and produce a fully cited scientific report. It has been verified by independent experts, reproducing three unpublished discoveries and proposing four new findings.
* **OpenAI's Interruption Support**: Allows users to modify deep research queries while preserving context state, enabling more efficient and accurate research.
* **Cursor's Semantic Code Retrieval**: Reports a 12.5% accuracy gain from semantic code retrieval and trains a custom embedding model for improved performance.
* **ElevenLabs' LLM Hosting**: Hosts LLMs inside Agents Platform to cut latency and reasoning cost for voice agents, improving their efficiency and effectiveness.
* **Perplexity's Open-Source Kernels**: Publishes open-source inter-node kernels for multi-node MoE scaling on AWS, making it more practical and efficient.
* **GitHub's MCP Registry**: Standardizes how users browse, install, and govern MCP servers, improving the overall development experience.
* **Agents in Production - Free Virtual Conference**: A free virtual conference on November 18, featuring talks from Meta and Microsoft, on how agents power search, shopping, and personalization.
* **Trending Papers**:
	+ Tencent and Tsinghua propose CALM, which stops predicting one token at a time and compresses chunks of tokens into continuous vectors.
	+ Google DeepMind's new paper reveals the framework behind its IMO win, introducing IMO-Bench to evaluate IMO-level math reasoning.
	+ LMArena launches Arena Expert to evaluate actual expert-level prompts, introducing a new Expert leaderboard and mapping prompts into 23 occupational fields.
* **Top Read**: An essay by Harvard computer scientist Boaz Barak on how rapid AI progress might disrupt traditional economic models, using data from AI capability scaling to test whether current theories of productivity and GDP growth still hold under exponential improvement.

### Important Links

* **Read on Web**: https://alphasignal.ai/email/bdee5230705a5d2f
